items.body:
Total.js Code editor is a server-side development editor targeted for creating Total.js web applications via a web browser. It offers a lot of features with real-time collaboration with your colleagues. - [Total.js Code on GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/code) - [Website](https://www.totaljs.com/code/) - [Try it in Cloud](https://platform.totaljs.com) - [Live chat with contributors](https://platform.totaljs.com?app=messenger) - [Commercial support](https://www.totaljs.com/support/) - [Service-level agreement (SLA)](https://www.totaljs.com/support/) __Requirements__: - Linux server - Node.js `+v16` - Total.js `+v4` < __IMPORTANT:__
Total.js Code Editor can edit entire files on your server, so be careful with usage. ## Electron version Electron version of Code editor offers you great additional features like quick access to multiple instances of Code editors and local storing of modified files due to tracking changes in source-version repositories like Git, Mercurial, etc... - [Code for MacOS (ARM 64)](https://cdn.totaljs.com/code/macos-arm64.zip) - [Code for MacOS (Intel)](https://www.dropbox.com/s/6t0fhe08y0bmsgp/code-mac.zip?dl=0) - [Code for Windows](https://www.dropbox.com/s/y0ooeasefr2vnpd/code-windows.zip?dl=0) < :fab fa-apple: __MacOS: How to Fix App "is damaged"__
Open terminal and write `xattr -cr /path/to/Code.app` and the Total.js Code will work. ## How to install Code editor? You have several ways how to provide a Total.js Code editor. ::: Docker: Server version This version doesn't limit your development. In one code editor, you can create a variety of apps. The code editor will run with every app as an independent Docker container. - follow install instructions ::: ::: Docker: Localhost - follow install instructions ::: ::: SuperAdmin - just register the app on some domain - then upload source-code and choose `Code` template ::: ```video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X2TY_MP4DqY ```

items.name: Welcome
items.body:
All configuration keys and values are stored in the `/config` file. The configuration file is a plain-text file that supports clear syntax. The configuration file is loaded when the framework is initializing.

```html
/app/config
/app/config-debug
/app/config-release
```

__Good to know__:

- you can read values from configuration via `CONF.key`
- configuration is read-only

::: Example

```config
name                         : My Web Site name
version                      : 1.01
author                       : Peter Sirka
secret                       : mySECRET1.01
default_image_quality        : 96
...
...
...
```
:::

::: Auto-Converting values with sub-type

The framework converts/binds values according to the sub-type. So you can read converted values in the application:

```config
my_custom_object_raw      (Object)    : { name: 'Total.js', date: new Date() }
my_custom_object_json     (JSON)      : { "name": "Total.js" }
my_custom_number          (number)    : 320.34
my_custom_boolean         (boolean)   : true
my_custom_date            (date)      : 2016-07-26
my_custom_array           (array)     : [1, 2, 3, 4]
binds_environment_value   (env)       : APP_NAME

// +v2.9.0 supports config linking
binds_config_value        (config)    : name
```
:::

::: Custom options for dependencies

`+v2.4.0` supports custom options for all dependencies.

```config
// type#name       (Object)  : { name: 'value', number: 30, boolean: false }
// a real example:
module#monitor     (Object)  : { url: '/mymonitor/'}
```
:::

::: Simple "encrypting" of values

`+v3.1.0` supports a simple encrypting of values with `base64` or `hex` encoding. Fox example:

```config
somevalue1            : base64 MTIzNDU2
// Contains 123456 value

somevalue2            : hex 313233343536
// Contains 123456 value
```
:::

::: Random values

`+v3.3.0` supports random values, example:

```config
somevalue1    (random)        : 10
// Will contain a random string with length 10 chars
```
:::

::: Generated persistent values

`+v3.4.0` supports persistent generated values, example:

```config
somevalue1    (generate)        : 10
// Will contain a random string with length 10 chars and stores it for future usage in /databases/config.json
```
:::

::: Good to know

__IMPORTANT__:

- `key : value` before the colon `:` must be at least one `space` or `\t`
- framework tries to parse a number (only numbers which not start with `0` zero) as number and boolean (`true` and `false`) as boolean, for example:

```config
will_be_number_1      : 123
will_be_number_2      : 0.3
will_not_be_number_1  : 0123
will_not_be_number_2  : 0,3

will_be_boolean_1     : true
will_be_boolean_2     : false
```
:::

__Reading data from configuration__:

```js
console.log(CONF.name);
```

items.name: Overview
items.body:
Each component should include the client-side UI (html, css and js) The UI uses [jComponent](/components/) library which uses jQuery under the hood. **Flow includes some predifined css classes**, check them first before defining new ones - [https://docs.totaljs.com/components/6212e001cc51c/](https://docs.totaljs.com/components/6212e001cc51c/) - [https://componentator.com/components/intranet-css/](https://componentator.com/components/intranet-css/) ## Styles: ```html ``` The CLASS will be automaticaly replaced by the formatted component name. It's essentially a lower-cased value of `exports.name = 'Trigger';` with f- --> `f-trigger`. This class is added to the wrapper element of the html in the body tag bellow in the Component section. ## Readme: ```html Component description here ``` The readme is shown after clicking "Read information" in the component context menu. ## Settings form: ```html
Name
 ``` The value of the above shown input is accessible on the server side in the `config` object passed to the `make` function ```javascript exports.make = function(instance, config) { config.name; // returns whatever the user entered in the input with a path ?.name }; ``` ## Component: The outer `body` tag is removed and the content is inserted into a `div` with a `.CLASS` class. The `CLASS` is variable mentioned bellow in the "Variables" section. ```html
NAME
``` To display a text in the footer > div you need to use `instance.status({ text: 'Hello world' });` in the server side code. ### Variables: - **NAME** - replaced by component name, e.g. Trigger - **ICON** - replaced by value of exports.icon - **STATUS** - replaced by the name of the scope generated for each instance. e.g. `!flow.status.ikzdtgzmq` - *The ! in data-bind path is optional and means it will only be processed if the data is not null or undefined. Read more about it [here](/components/40d04001gw51c/#advanced-usage) in the Advanced usage section --> Nullable values* - **CLASS** - replaced by formated name: 'My trigger' --> 'mytrigger' - **CONFIG** - replaced by config path: `flow.config.xyz` where xyz is instance id - **ID** - replaced by component id (NOT an instance id) - **UID** - replaced by instance id

items.body: **Paths** examples and explanation. --- **Simple path:** Example: `user`, `users.form`, etc. ```html ``` The above will be rendered as shown bellow: ```html Hello world ``` --- **Scoped path:** Example: `?.name`, `?.address.street`, etc. Scoped path uses `?` which is internaly replaced by the scope of the nearest element above with a scope. ```html ``` --- **Temporary path:** Example: `%search`, etc. It is possible to use `%` to create a temporaty path. ```html Search: ``` This will create a `search` property in temp object, it looks like this under the hood: ```javascript window.jctmp.search = 'whatever user types in the searchinput'; ``` --- **Isolated path:** Useful in the case where a parent element has a scope but we don't want to use it. So to ignore the parent's scope just use `isolated:true` in the `ui-plugin` attribute. ```html Name Name ```

items.name: Welcome to Flow v10+
items.body:
__Total.js Flow v10__ is highly customizable and advanced. Unlike previous versions, version 10 uses the built-in [Total.js framework's FlowStream algorithm](/total4/5aed1001bj51c/).

- :far fa-life-ring #E73323: [__Free online chat support__](https://t.me/totaljs/6030) 

---

- [Documentation: __FlowStream algorithm__](/total4/5aed1001bj51c/)
- [Flow tutorials](https://blog.totaljs.com/tutorials/?q=flow)
- [Website](https://www.totaljs.com/flow/)

## Installation

### :far fa-code: Download source-code

- [Node.js v14 or higher](https://nodejs.org)
- [Download the project from GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/flow)

To run the app locally, open a terminal and type:

```bash
$ npm install
$ npm start
```

### :fab fa-docker: Docker

To run the app as a Docker container, open a terminal and type:

```bash
docker pull totalplatform/flow
docker run -p 8000:8000 totalplatform/flow
```

---

By default the app will be accessible at [127.0.0.1:8000](http://127.0.0.1:8000). The port can be changed in the `package.json` file or update Docker port mapping.

When you visit the above mentioned url you will be asked to login using the provided credentials. You can change the password later in the setting menu.

```video
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1fqQeO7Tork
```

items.name: Overview
items.body:
__Operation system__:

- :fab fa-apple: `CMD` for MacOS
- :fab fa-windows: `CTRL` for Windows
- :fab fa-linux: `CTRL` for Linux

---

| Shortcut | Description |
|----------|-------------|
| `CMD+A`  | Select one component and press CTRL+A or CMD+A to select all connected components. Pressing CTRL+A or CMD+A while no component selected will select all the components in the designer |
| `CMD+C`  | Copies selected components to the clipboard, including the source code so it can be pasted in another FlowStream instance even if the copied components are not installed there |
| `CMD+V`  | Pastes components from clipboard, if any of the components is not installed it will be installed automatically |
| `CMD+D`  | Duplicates the selected components |
| `CMD+S`  | Saves changes and close in editor |
| `CMD+CLICK` | Can select multiple components |

items.name: How can I restart a specifc thread?
items.body: If your app is running under debug mode, the changed thread will be automatically restarted. Otherwise, make an empty plain text file in the form `restart_THREADNAME` in the app's root, and the main process will restart a specific thread.

items.name: Welcome
items.body:
__Total.js project__ contains a simple directory structure, and all directories are optional. You can choose what you want to use and when.

:far fa-running: __Loading directories is in this order__:

1. `jsonschemas`
1. `modules`
1. `packages`
1. `models`
1. `schemas`
1. `tasks`
1. `operations`
1. `themes`
1. `definitions`
1. `controllers`
1. `components`
1. `middleware`
1. `builds`
1. `extensions`
1. `plugins`
1. `preferences`

__Directories__:

```text
/builds/
/bundles/
/components/
/controllers/
/databases/
/definitions/
/extensions/
/jsonschemas/
/middleware/
/modules/
/operations/
/packages/
/private/
/public/
/resources/
/schemas/
/views/
/updates/
/workers/
```

__Files__:

```text
/config
/index.js
```

- `config` can contain app configuration
- `index.js` is start script for web application (more in the [__Running__ section](/total4/6b8ac001nf51c/))

## Directories

::: `/builds/` directory

This directory can contain Total.js builds from Total.js Application Builder. `build` is a plain-text file that contains design architecture and compiled code. The build can be created/modified by Total.js Code Editor or via SuperAdmin.

:::

::: `/bundles/` directory

This directory can contain Total.js bundles only. `bundle` is a single-file package that includes some application files or directories. We provide most of the Total.js applications as bundles in release mode. Read more in __Bundles__ section.

:::

::: `/components/` directory

This directory can contain only `.html` files with the implementation of the Total.js component. Read more in __Components__ section.

:::

::: `/controllers/` directory

This directory can contain `.js` files only. Read more in __Controllers__ section.

:::

::: `/databases/` directory

This directory can contain TextDB databases and some other helper files. You can use this directory for storing some persistent data.

:::

::: `/definitions/` directory

This directory can contain `.js` Total.js definition files. Definition files can contain some definitions for services, authorization, processing of connection strings, etc. These definition files are evaluated when the framework is starting.

:::

::: `/extensions/` directory

This directory can contain `.js` Total.js extension files, but only for testing purpose. For the production we recommend to use [`NEWEXTENSION()` method](/total4/407ff001jy51c/#d6fe5001fs51c) that evaluates `String` as a regular `js` code.

:::

::: `/jsonschemas/` directory

This directory can contain valid JSON schemas `.json`. JSON schemas can be used in the Total.js schemas or in Total.js Message Service. __Schemas are loaded when the framework is initializing.__

- [JSON schema specification](http://json-schema.org/)

:::

::: `/middleware/` directory

This directory can contain `.js` files with defined Total.js middleware.

:::

::: `/modules/` directory

This directory can contain `.js` Total.js modules. Modules mean reusable code for various Total.js applications.

- [Download modules](https://github.com/totaljs/modules)

:::

::: `/operations/` directory

This directory can contain `.js` files. Operations can contain Total.js operations defined via `NEWOPERATION()` method.

- [Download operations](https://github.com/totaljs/operations)

:::

::: `/packages/` directory

This directory can contain `.package` files. Packages are something like bundles, but they are evaluated as `modules` independently.

- [Flow](https://github.com/totaljs/flow)
- [Dashboard](https://github.com/totaljs/dashboard)
- [FlowBoard](https://github.com/totaljs/flowboard)
- [Mini HelpDesk](https://github.com/totaljs/helpdeskpackage)

:::

::: `/private/` directory

This directory is targeted for storing private files. We use this directory for storing e.g. `certificates` or `scripts`.

:::

::: `/public/` directory

This directory is a public directory, __ so that you can download everything in this directory__ via the network. Be careful about what you want to store.

Only file extensions are allowed, which are defined in `Configuration` under keys: `static_accepts` or `static_accepts_custom`.

:::

::: `/resources/` directory

This directory can contain only `.resource` resource files. A resource file contains localization in the form `key : value` similarly to in the configuration file.

:::

::: `/schemas/` directory

This directory can contain only `.js` Total.js schemas defined via the `NEWSCHEMA()` method. Read more in the `Schemas` section.
:::

::: `/themes/` directory

This directory can contain Total.js themes. Read more in the `Themes` section.

:::

::: `/views/` directory

This directory can contain only `.html` Total.js views. Read more in the `View engine` section.

:::

::: `/updates/` directory

This directory can contain `.js` scripts for performing updates in e.g., your database. The framework will evaluate every script only once, and then the scripts will be renamed to `yourscriptname.js_bk`.

- Read more in [`UPDATE()` method](/total4/407ff001jy51c/#4ab26001ji51c)

:::

::: `/workers/` directory

This directory can contain only `.js` scripts, which are evaluated in the independent thread.

:::

## Internal directories

::: `/.src/` directory

This directory contains extracted and merged source-code from bundles, so if you use `bundles`, this directory will contain raw source-code.

::: 

::: `/tmp/` directory

This directory contains temporary files generated by the framework. __Don't delete files and folders__ in this folder __manually__, because the framework cleans them automatically.

:::

::: `/logs/` directory

The framework generates this directory, and the directory will contain some logs from the Total.js application.

:::

items.name: Intro
items.body:
Welcome to the __Total.js framework__ documentation. __Total.js__ is a __Node.js framework__ targeted at creating __server-side__ web applications, REST services, real-time applications, and much more. This documentation contains all information about the Total.js framework __version 4__.

- :far fa-life-ring #E73323: [__Free online chat support__](https://t.me/totaljs/6033) 

__Minimum requirements:__

- [Node.js +14](https://nodejs.org/en/)
- CPU: 1x single core
- Memory (RAM): 30 MB
- Free hard drive space: 15 MB
- OS: Linux, Unix or Windows

< We will disappoint you if you want to use __TypeScript__ or some additional tools to create web applications. We have optimized the Total.js platform to develop web applications directly in __Notepad__ or __Nano editor__ without any special 3rd party tools; that's the mission of Total.js Platform - __be independent__.

- [__Guidelines__](/welcome/67b47001ty51c/)
- [Framework on GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/framework4)
- [Website](https://www.totaljs.com)
- [Examples](https://github.com/totaljs/examples)
- [Try Total.js Rapid Cloud Development](https://platform.totaljs.com?open=cloud)
- [Live chat with contributors](https://platform.totaljs.com?open=messenger)
- [Commercial support](https://www.totaljs.com/support/)
- We offer [Service-level agreement (SLA)](https://www.totaljs.com/contact/)

---

__Good to know__:

- [__Total.js v3 documentation__](https://docs.totaljs.com/latest/en.html)

The differences between Total.js 4 and Total.js 3 are significant, so for backward compatibility and future fixes of old Total.js 3, we moved new Total.js 4 to an NPM repository called `total4`.

- __Total.js 3__ installation: `$ npm install total.js`
- __Total.js 4__ installation: `$ npm install total4`

---

__Framework contains__:

- Web server
- Handling of static files
- Powerful request routing
- SMTP sender
- NoSQL embedded database called TextDB
- Image handling via GraphicsMagick or ImageMagick
- Data models
- WebSocket and WebSocket client
- Scheduler
- Workers
- File storage
- Data Flow architecture
- Components
- Versioning
- Clustering
- Source-code bundling
- Number, String, Date and Array prototypes
- and much, much more ...

< __You don't need any dependencies__ to create powerful server-side JavaScript applications (except DB connectors or some specific modules). __Total.js framework__ was built on many years of experience and offers many resources within a great application architecture.

items.name: Welcome
items.body:
Each technology/language has its limit, and everything depends on the project structure and architecture. For example, the `C` language is fast, a lot faster than JavaScript/PHP/Python/etc... Still, at some point, you will need to perform the same or similar steps for optimization as in slower technology/language. So, I try to explain how to optimize/think of a project architecture within the Total.js platform. We divided projects according to the count of concurrent requests. But the concurrency may not be the critical issue, and everything depends on what your application does (what kind of operations the app performs, etc.). The Total.js framework can handle around 1000 requests per second in a single thread. __We recommend using__ a microservice architecture with the Total.js framework. < __Good to know__:
Every more significant project uses multiple various technologies and tools, and we will be happy if Total.js will be one of them. ## Small projects up to `1K` concurrent requests Small projects are the best projects because you are not limited to create anything. You don't need to worry about coding, just code and create something extraordinary. In small projects, you can use Total.js Text DB and many internal features like in-memory databases or global variables `MAIN`, `REPO`, `PREF` for storing temporary/long-term data. As we wrote above: the Total.js framework can handle around 1000 requests per second in a single thread. - [Small project architecture](https://www.figma.com/file/omVdmvybAsSHgegOSnHWvZ/Total.js-small-project?node-id=0%3A1) ## Medium projects up to `10K` concurrent requests For medium projects, you need to think in cluster mode and prepare extraordinary architecture for your application. That means that your application will run (will be cloned) several times on one server, and these independent instances/apps won't see each other. Each app will have its own independent variables (not shared), memory (not shared), and performance. And that's the problem you need to solve, sharing states between all instances. For this case, you need to have one extra unique app called a state machine for storing, e.g. user sessions. You can use REDIS, Memcached, or create something own in the Total.js framework - just create an app with WebSocket route and connect each instance of your app to this app via `WEBSOCKETCLIENT()`, or use Total.js Message Service (TMS) as the communication channel for your state machine. - [Medium project architecture](https://www.figma.com/file/EVK02l5EQQ6FzKzrW4v8b3/Total.js-medium-project?node-id=0%3A1) - [__C10k problem__](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C10k_problem) --- __How to run Total.js in the cluster mode?__ You can run your __Total.js app__ easily with the help of [Total.js Cluster](/total4/71e36001ip51c/), this mode uses [Node.js Cluster module](https://nodejs.org/dist/latest-v14.x/docs/api/cluster.html). If you have performance issues with the Total.js Cluster, then you can create your solution. You can run the Total.js application several times in various ports. Then you can easily set up a load balancer in your reverse proxy, e.g. [NGINX example](https://docs.nginx.com/nginx/admin-guide/load-balancer/http-load-balancer/). ## Large projects for unlimited concurrent requests We don't have any experience with large projects, but we drew some architecture diagram, how is possible to create a large project. - [Large project architecture](https://www.figma.com/file/NPtdZHUrsLifDViVz1tfjX/Total.js-large-project?node-id=0%3A1) Of course, you need to think more than in clusterization. Here, clusterization is more advanced because you need to cluster the app, the entire server, and the load balancer. You will have several load balancers with implemented GeoDNS.

items.name: Intro
items.body:
__OpenMail__ is a lightweight mail SMTP sender that allows you to create multiple SMTP profiles with their HTML templates.

- __MIT license__
- [OpenMail on GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/openmail)
- Supports [Total.js Extensions](/extensions/)
- [__Support Total.js Platform__](https://www.totaljs.com/community/)

## Installation

- [Node.js +v14](https://nodejs.org)

__Docker__:

```bash
$ docker pull totalplatform/openmail
$ docker run -p 8000:8000 -d totalplatform/openmail
```

__or__ [download the project from GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/openmail):

```bash
$ cd openmail
$ npm install
$ npm start
```

- :far fa-globe: Then visit setup: <http://127.0.0.1:8000> 

## Sending mail messages

```request
POST https://openmail.yourserver.com/?token=YOUR_OPENMAIL_TOKEN
Content-Type: application/json

{
	"id": "profile_reference/template_reference",
	"to": "email address", // it can contain multiple address divided by comma
	"data": {
		"custom_model": "for the template"
	}
}
```

__Optional fields__:

- `subject {String}` by default is obtained from the template
- `reply {String}` a reply-to address
- `cc {String}` CC address
- `bcc {String}` BCC address
- `attachments {Array Object}`
	- in the form `[{ name: 'filename.txt', url: 'https://www.myserver.com/filename.txt' }]`

### Good to know

__OpenMail__ supports sending requests as `multipart/form-data` content-type. But `object` stored in the `data` field must be serialized in JSON format. Then the files will be used as Mail message attachments.

items.name: Intro
items.body:
Total.js Macros are targeted for adding a simple functionality to your Total.js application by adding custom user scripts. These scripts contain simpler syntax than JavaScript, and the result is compiled into the raw JavaScript function.

- you don't need to distinguish Upper/Lower cases
- supports custom helpers
- supports conditions
- supports a temporary object
- user defined values must wrapped to the quotes, example: `"value"`
- `"yes"`, `"no"`, `"true"`, `"false"` is considered as a boolean
- `"100"` or `100` is considered as a number

< :far fa-exclamation-triangle: The model for the macro must contain lower-case keys/properties.

__Example__:

```js
var fn = NEWMACRO(`
VALUE = VALUE + 10
RETURN VALUE
`);

console.log(fn({ value: 10 }));
// Output: 20
```

## Language

__Basics__:

```text
VALUE = vaLUe + "10" + 10
// is same as
value = value + 10 + 10
```

__Conditions__:

```text
IF age = 30
	RETURN true
FI
```

```text
IF age < 18
	RETURN "too young"
ELSE IF age < 50
	RETURN "ok"
ELSE
	RETURN "too old"
FI
```

__Temporary values__:

```text
#plus = 10
RETURN value + #plus
```

__Custom helpers__:

```text
IF naMe="PETER" AND Age >= 35 AND CONTAINS(tags, "total")
	RETURN 100 * "100"
FI
```

items.name: Intro
items.body:
__OpenDB__ is a lightweight flat-file NoSQL database engine to store small amount of data, in-memory session data, or files. The database contains many excellent features and a simple type of communication controlled from the command line. The project is without any 3rd party dependencies with low hardware requirements.

- __MIT license__
- [OpenDB on GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/opendb)
- Supports [Total.js Extensions](/extensions/)
- Supports [Total.js Message Service](/tms/)

## Installation

- [Node.js +v14](https://nodejs.org)

__Docker__:

```bash
$ docker pull totalplatform/opendb
$ docker run -p 8000:8000 -d totalplatform/opendb
```

__or__ [download the project from GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/opendb):

```bash
$ cd opendb
$ npm install
$ npm start
```

- :far fa-globe: Then visit setup: <http://127.0.0.1:8000> 

## Communication

- [DBMS module supports OpenDB](/dbms/)

### WebSocket

- Text communication (data serialized in JSON format)
- URL address: `wss://opendb.yourserver.com/?token=YOUR_TOKEN`
- OpenDB socket will send `init` message:

```js
{
	type: 'init',
	name: 'OpenDB instance name',
	version: 1,
	id: 'OpenDB'
}
```

::: Request message
```js
{
	db: 'users',
	type: 'find',
	callbackid: '1',
	filter: 'true'
}
```
:::

::: Response
```js
{
	callbackid: '1',
	response: Array/Object/Number
	error: Undefined/String
}
```
:::

### REST

__Request example__:

```request
POST https://opendb.yourserver.com/?token=YOUR_TOKEN
Content-Type: application/json

{
	"db": "users",
	"type": "find",
	"filter": "true"
}
```

__HTTP statuses__:

- `==200` returns `Array/Object/Number` 
- `>=400` returns `Array Object` with errors

items.creator: Peter Širka

items.name: modify
items.body:
This command modifies data into the database.

### 1. usage

It updates only the fields defined in the `data` property.

```js
{
	db: 'users',
	type: 'modify',
	filter: 'doc.id==arg.id',
	filterarg: { arg: '123456' },
	data: { id: '12345', name: 'Peter', '+age': 5, '!isconfirmed': 1 }
}
```

__Atomic operations__:

- `+key: value` increments a number about defined value
- `-key: value` decrements a number about defined value
- `/key: value` divides a number about defined value
- `*key: value` multiples a number about defined value
- `!key: true` performs toggle for Boolean values
- `<key: value` performs `Math.max(doc[key], value)`
- `>key: value` performs `Math.min(doc[key], value)`

### 2. usage

```js
{
	db: 'users',
	type: 'modify',
	filter: 'doc.id==arg.id',
	filterarg: { arg: '123456' },
	modify: 'doc.name=doc.name.toUpperCase();doc.age+=arg.age',
	modifyarg: { age: 5 }
}
```

---

- __Response:__ `{Number}`

items.name: Intro
items.body:
OpenDB uses JavaScript syntax (hidden arrow function) for filtering documents.

```js
{
	type: 'find',
	filter: 'doc.id===arg.id',
	filterarg: { id: '123456' }
}
```

::: `type {String}`
__Required__. It must contain one of the below type.
:::

::: `db {String}`
__Required__. It must contain a database name in lower-case. Allowed only `a-z` chars.
:::

::: `fields {String}`
It can contain fields that you need to be separated by a comma. __Fields can't contain nested fields.__

```js
{
	fields: 'id,name'
}
```

__or without fields__:

```js
{
	fields: '-name,-age'
}
```
:::

::: `filter {String}`
It's basically an arrow function in the form `(doc, arg, tmp) => your_filter`

- `doc` document read from the database
- `arg` custom arguments defined in `filterarg`
- `tmp` a temporary empty object
:::

::: `filterarg {Object}`
It contains additional arguments that are assigned as the filter `arg` argument
:::

::: `take {Number}`
It takes a specific count of documents.
:::

::: `limit {Number}`
Alias for the `take` key.
:::

::: `skip {Number}`
It skips a specific count of documents.
:::

::: `sort {String}`
It performs sorting in the form `column_asc` or `colum_desc`. Sorting supports multiple keys separated by comma.
:::

::: `first {Boolean}`
It returns only the first found document.
:::

::: `id {String}`
It's targeted for `stats` types (it's a unique identifier for storing statistic data).
:::

::: `data {Object}`
It can contain a payload for `insert/update/stats_save` types. __Data must contain object__.
:::

::: `modify {String}`
It's basically an arrow function in the form `(doc, arg, tmp) => your_document_modification`

- `doc` document read from the database
- `arg` custom arguments defined in `modifyarg`
- `tmp` a temporary empty object
:::

::: `modifyarg {Object}`
It contains additional arguments that are assigned as the modify `arg` argument.
:::

::: `scalar {String}`
It's basically an arrow function in the form `(doc, arg, tmp) => your_document_modification`.

- `doc` document read from the database
- `arg` custom arguments defined in `scalararg`
- `tmp` a temporary empty object
:::

::: `scalararg {Object}`
It contains additional arguments that are assigned as the modify `arg` argument. In the `scalar` mode, you can get back `scalararg` value as the response.
:::

::: `expire {String}`
Set an expiration for in-memory read type. It can be in the form of `1 hour`, `3 minutes`, etc..
:::

::: `callbackid {String}`
__Required__ only for WebSocket communication. A value stored in `callbackid` will be returned in the incoming message.
:::

__Good to know__:

- `take` affects modify/remove types

---

items.name: Intor
items.body:
The `QueryBuilder` contains a simple ORM implementation for various database engines. Unfortunately, `QueryBuilder` is an abstraction layer, and you need to download existing implementations for QueryBuilder or create your own. < __Good to know__:
The `QueryBuilder` can be serialized into the JSON. __Existing implementations__: - NoSQL embedded (TextDB) driver included in the Total.js core - [QueryBuilder for PostgreSQL](https://github.com/totaljs/querybuilderpg) - [QueryBuilder for MySQL](https://github.com/totaljs/querybuildermysql2) - [QueryBuilder for SQLite](https://github.com/totaljs/querybuildersqlite3) __Example__: ``` DB().find('nosql/frameworks').where('id', 'Total.js').callback(console.log); ``` The QueryBuilder contains two implementations: - Database operations - Query operations for fitering data

items.name: Intro
items.body:
We provide a website [Componentator.com](https://componentator.com) which offers browsing of more than 290 Web Components for free and fully open-source.

- [Download free and open-source UI components](https://componentator.com)
- [UI components on GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/components)

## Componentator for the web development

We have prepared two endpoints on Componentator.com to help you build better client-side apps. So you can easily include all UI components with their declarations (JS+CSS). It's easy to download the source code and include it directly in the project without external links to our services or CDN.

< :far fa-thumbs-up: The Total.js framework provides the [`COMPONENTATOR()` method](https://docs.totaljs.com/total4/407ff001jy51c/#x6vp001kb41d) method for downloading components into a project and caching them for use.

__Example__:

```html
https://componentator.com/download.js?id=component1,component2
```

__Query arguments__:

- `id=component1,component2` component identifiers separated by the comma
- `css=0` disables injecting CSS
- `darkmode=0` disables dark-mode for CSS
- `minify=0` disables JS/CSS minification

Componentator will respond with the `.js` file with all component declarations. If you prefer the independent `.css` library, the Componentator supports the `/download.css` endpoint with the exact implementation as `/download.js`.

items.name: Intro
items.body:
API Call is generated by the calling of [`API()` method](/total4/407ff001jy51c/#rspo001cs41d). The method returns `API Call` instance and the instance contains the methods declared below.

```js
var api = API('Payments', 'payments_insert', { amount: 100 });
```

__One line example__:

```js
API('Payments', 'payments_insert', { amount: 100 }).callback(console.log).error('A trouble with API');
```

__Total.js API services__ (built-in):

```js
API('TAPI', 'sms', { to: '+421903163302', from: 'Total.js', body: 'Hello world' }).callback(console.log);
```

items.name: Intro
items.body:
__OpenLogger__ is a lightweight app for storing logs from 3rd party apps. Logs are stored on HDD into the NoSQL embedded database. You can easily browse and filter stored logs in the OpenLogger setup interface.

- __MIT license__
- [OpenLogger on GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/openlogger)
- Supports [Total.js Extensions](/extensions/)
- [__Support Total.js Platform__](https://www.totaljs.com/community/)

## Installation

- [Node.js +v14](https://nodejs.org)

__Docker__:

```bash
$ docker pull totalplatform/openlogger
$ docker run -p 8000:8000 -d totalplatform/openlogger
```

__or__ [download the project from GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/openlogger):

```bash
$ cd openlogger
$ npm install
$ npm start
```

- :far fa-globe: Then visit setup: <http://127.0.0.1:8000> 

## REST API

The app supports only the one API endpoint for inserting log:

__Request__:

```request
POST https://youropenloggerinstance.com/?token=YOUR_TOKEN
Content-Type: application/json

{
	"type": String,        // required, it can contain only "info", "warning", "error" or "success" value
	"data": String,        // optional, for storing variable JSON object
	"app": String,         // optional, app name where the log is created
	"url": String,         // optional, URL address
	"userid": String,      // optional, user identifier
	"username": String,    // optional, user name
	"schema": String,      // optional, schema name or model name
	"reference": String,   // optional, a custom reference number
	"message": String,     // optional, a custom message
	"ua": String,          // optional, user-agent
	"ip": String           // optional, IP address
}
```

__Response__:

```js
{
    success: true
}
```

## Total.js Audit logs

Make a definition file e.g. `logger.js` and put the code below:

```js
DEF.onAudit = function(name, data) {
	data.app = CONF.name;
	data.sessionid = data.thread = undefined;
	RESTBuilder.POST('https://youropenlogger.com/?token=1234567890', data).keepalive().callback(ERROR('Logger'));
};
```

Then, you can use audit logs in the Total.js schemas directly:

```js
// $.audit([message], [type]);
// @message {String} optional
// @type {String} optional, it can contain a value: "info" (default), "error" or "warning"
$.audit('Update schema: ' + model.name);
```

__OpenFiles__ is a lightweight app for storing files from 3rd party apps. Files are stored on HDD in the Total.js FileStorage. You can easily browse and filter stored files in the OpenFiles setup interface.

- __MIT license__
- [OpenFiles on GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/openfiles)
- Supports [Total.js Extensions](/extensions/)
- [__Support Total.js Platform__](https://www.totaljs.com/community/)

## Installation

- [Node.js +v14](https://nodejs.org)

__Docker__:

```bash
$ docker pull totalplatform/openfiles
$ docker run -p 8000:8000 -d totalplatform/openfiles
```

__or__ [download the project from GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/openfiles):

```bash
$ cd openfiles
$ npm install
$ npm start
```

- :far fa-globe: Then visit setup: <http://127.0.0.1:8000>

---

items.name: POST /upload/{database}/?token=YOUR_TOKEN
items.body:
The endpoint saves uploaded file/files.

- Content-Type: `multipart`

__Additional query attributes__:

- `&hostname=1` will return an absolute URL address in the response
- `&id=123456` optional, a file identifier

__Response__:

```js
{
	id: String,
	name: String,
	size: Number,    // in bytes
	type: String,    // content type
	width: Number,   // image width
	height: Number,  // image height
	ext: String,     // file extension
	url: String      // URL address to this file (relative or absolute)
}
```

__Good to know__:

- a single upload will respond with the `Object`
- a multi-file upload will respond with the `Object Array`

items.name: POST /base64/{database}/?token=YOUR_TOKEN
items.body:
The endpoint saves uploaded Base64.

- Content-Type: `application/json`
- __Data must be in the form:__ `{ name: String, file: Content-Type;Base64 }`

__Additional query attributes__:

- `&hostname=1` will return an absolute URL address in the response

__Response__:

```js
{
	id: String,
	name: String,
	size: Number,    // in bytes
	type: String,    // content type
	width: Number,   // image width
	height: Number,  // image height
	ext: String,     // file extension
	url: String      // URL address to this file (relative or absolute)
}
```

__Example__:

```request
POST https://youropenfilesinstance.com/?token=123456
Content-Type: application/json

{
	"name": "logo.jpg",
	"file": "data:image/jpeg;SW1hZ2VCYXN...."
}
```

items.name: Intro
items.body:
Welcome to the Total.js UI Builder documentation. These pages contain basic information about the UI builder, its templates and components. UI Builder is still a beta version, but it has fixed core functionality. So, we don't expect breaking changes in the near future and you can build your apps without any problem. - [GitHub source code](https://github.com/totaljs/uibuilder/) ## UI Studio Our recommendation is to start with Total.js UI Studio, which fully integrates the UI Builder editor and compiler. - [Download UI Studio](https://github.com/totaljs/uistudio) ## How does it work? Total.js UI Builder is an editor for creating dynamic UI designs. Design consists of a JSON object with a clearly defined structure. Total.js UI Builder has no backend, so it is purely front-end-oriented. UI design is collected from two designs: editor and build. The build cannot be edited in the editor and is designed for production. < :fa fa-question-circle: __Good to know__:
A component can have defined inputs and outputs which are an integral part of UI Builder, because UI designs can communicate among themselves through inputs and outputs. __JSON contains:__ - List of components (links or source code of the components serialized in Base64) - Design structure - Global data - Inputs/Outputs You can find all the prepared UI Builder templates here: , and of course, you can create your own.

items.name: instance.state
items.body:
This property contains a current state of the object instance.

```js
instance.state;
// returns {Object}
```

__Properties__:

- `value {Object}` a current value of the object
- `disabled {Boolean}` is the object disabled?
- `readonly {Boolean}` is the object readonly?
- `touched {Boolean}` is the object directly in contact with the user?
- `modified {Boolean}` is the object modified?

__Internal properties__:

- `bind {Boolean}` the component will be available for e.g. form binding (default: `false`)
- `validate {Boolean}` the component will be validated automatically via `instance.validate` delegate (default: `true`)
- `notify {Boolean}` the component will be notified about the changing value in the `notify` event, so value will not be bound automatically to the component (default: `false`)

items.name: schema.action(name, opt)
items.body:
Registers a new schema action.

```js
schema.action(name, opt)
// @name {String} name of action
// @opt {Object} additional options
```

__`opt` fields:__

- `name {String}` optional, a humanable action name
- `params {String}` optional, params schema
- `query {String}` optional, query arguments schema
- `input {String}` optional, input data schema
- `output {String}` optional, output data schema
- `action {Function($, model)}` __required__ a function that will be executed
- `publish {String/Boolean}` optional, performs `NEWPUBLISH()` with declared data
	- if `true` then it will copy data from the `input` or `output` argument
	- `string` must contain data schema
	- `+string` will extend input or output data argument
- `user {Boolean}` optional, the `$.user` instance must exist if `true`
- `permissions {String/String Array}` optional, the framework will call the `UNAUTHORIZED($, permissions)` method
- `sa {Boolean}` optional, the `$.user.sa` must be `true`
- __NEW__: `cache {Object}` optional, can cache output:
	- `user {Boolean}` optional, `user.id` will be used in the cache key
	- `params {Boolean}` optional, `params` will be used in the cache key
	- `query {String}` optional, `key1,key2,key3` will be used in the cache key
	- `language {Boolean}` optional, `language` will be used in the cache key
	- `expire {String}` optional, expiration time e.g. `1 minute` (default: `5 minutes`)

__Good to know__:

- :fa fa-warning: `input` data schema works if you don't declare `schema.define()` otherwise you can have multiple actions with various input data schemas
- `output` data schema is used for output data, so output data will be transformed automatically according to this schema
- data types don't depend on the case sensitivity
- you can call action from everywhere via the [`CALL()` method](/total4/407ff001jy51c/#tawa001tj41d)

### Data schema

Data schema supports all basic types + arrays:

- `number`
- `tinyint`
- `smallin`
- `number`
- `boolean`
- `string`
- `guid`
- `uid`
- `date`
- `string`
- `email`
- `zip`
- `phone`
- `url`
- `json`
- `base64`
- `lowercase`
- `uppercase`
- `capitalize`
- `capitalize2`
- `icon` supports only Total.js Icons or Font-Awesome
- `color` must be defined in HEX
- __NEW__ supports enums in the form `{enumA|enumB|enumC}`
- __NEW__ supports nested objects in the form `{ name:String, age:Number }`
- __NEW__ supports nested object arrays in the form `[name:String, age:Number]`
- __NEW__ supports linkers to other Total.js Schemas `name:@Profile, address:@Address`

The schema must be defined in the form: `name:String, age:Number` separated by the comma or newline. If you want to have something required e.g. `name` field, then use: `*name:String`. Array must be defined like `[String]`. The schema is designed for one-level defined properties/fields.

__Examples__:

```js
schema.action('find', {
	query: 'page:Number, sort:String',
	params: 'projectid:String',
	action: function($) {
		// $.query
		// $.params
		$.success();
	}
});

schema.action('save', {
	input: '*name:String, age:Number',
	output: 'success:Boolean',
	params: 'projectid:String, id:String',
	action: function($, model) {
		// $.query
		// $.params
		// $.model or model "is prepared according to the input data schema"

		// $.success();
		// $.callback({ success: true });

		// TMS:
		// $.publish(model);
	}
});
```

items.name: Intro
items.body:
__OpenTemplates__ is a lightweight app for creating HTML templates that can be printed as PDF/DOCX/JPG file types. OpenTemplates is designed for integration with third-party apps to generate various templates including invoices, contracts, etc.

The app is without dependencies. Run it, use it.

- __MIT license__
- [OpenTemplates on GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/opentemplates)
- Supports [Total.js Extensions](/extensions/)
- [__Support Total.js Platform__](https://www.totaljs.com/community/)

## Installation

- [Node.js +v14](https://nodejs.org)

__Docker__:

```bash
$ docker pull totalplatform/opentemplates
$ docker run -p 8000:8000 -d totalplatform/opentemplates
```

__or__ [download the project from GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/opentemplates):

```bash
$ cd opentemplates
$ npm install
$ npm start
```

- :far fa-globe: Then visit setup: <http://127.0.0.1:8000> 

## Rendering templates

```request
POST https://opentemplates.yourserver.com/?token=YOUR_OPENTEMPLATES_TOKEN
Content-Type: application/json

{
	"id": "profile_reference/template_reference",
	"output": "pdf",
	"margin": "10 10 10 10", // optional in "mm" unit, form: "top right bottom left" and default value is "0 0 0 0"
	"data": {
		"custom_model": "for the template"
	}
}
```

__Output types__:

- `html` (default)
- `pdf` needed Total.js API token
- `jpg` needed Total.js API token
- `docx` needed Total.js API token

This property contains a default prefix for Font icons used in the components.

```js
DEF.iconprefix = 'ti ti-';
// return String;
```

- list of icons <https://cdn.componentator.com/icons.html>

```js
DEF.iconprefix = 'fa fa-';
```

__Default values__:

- `v19` uses `ti ti-`
- `v18` uses `fa fa-`

items.name: String.parseHTML([trim])
items.body:
Parses HTML to an object. ```js String.parseHTML([trim]); // @trim {Boolean} optional (default: false) // returns HTMLElement; ``` ## HTMLElement ```js var dom = '
Hello world!
'.parseHTML(); ``` __Properties__: - `dom.innerHTML {String}` returns HTML - `dom.innerText {String}` returns content without tags __Methods__: - `dom.parent() {HTMLElement}` returns parent element - `dom.closest(selector) {HTMLElement}` finds closest element - `dom.aclass(cls) {HTMLElement}` adds class(es) - `dom.rclass(cls) {HTMLElement}` removes class(es) - `dom.tclass(cls) {HTMLElement}` toggles class(es) - `dom.hclass(cls) {Boolean}` determines class - `dom.attr(name, [value]) {String/HTMLElement}` sets/reads attribute and its value - `dom.css(name, value) {HTMLElement}` sets CSS - `dom.remove()` removes element - `dom.text()` returns content without tags - `dom.html()` returns HTML - `dom.append(html)` appends HTML - `dom.prepend(html)` prepends HTML - `dom.find(selector) {Array of HTMLElement}` and extended by these methods: - `result.aclass(cls)` adds class(es) to all found elements - `result.rclass(cls)` removes class(es) to all found elements - `result.tclass(cls)` toggles class(es) to all found elements - `result.attr(name, value)` sets attribute + its value to all found elements - `result.find(selector)` performs `find` in all found elements < __Good to know__:
`dom.find()` method returns `Array`, so you must work with every element individually.

items.name: Intro
items.body:
OpenPlatform (MIT license) is a simple enterprise-ready platform for running, integrating, and managing multiple 3rd party web applications. OpenPlatform is a simple container for users and third-party applications independent of client-side/server-side technologies.

- :far fa-life-ring #E73323: [__Free online chat support__](https://t.me/totaljs/6031) 
- [__OpenPlatform website__](https://www.totaljs.com/openplatform/)
- [Repository on GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/openplatform/)
- [Need help? __Professional support__](https://www.totaljs.com/support/)
- [Commercial support](https://www.totaljs.com/support/)
- [Service-level agreement (SLA)](https://www.totaljs.com/support/)

![OpenPlatform](/download/xav3001kb41d-1si7hid-640x492-1.gif)

## Installation

:fa fa-warning: WARNING: Please do not execute `database.sql`, this script will use OpenPlatform internally.

- [Video tutorial](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Qud6SlIUQM)

__Manual installation__:

- Install latest version of [__Node.js platform__](https://nodejs.org/en/)
- Install PostgreSQL
- Create a database for the OpenPlatform
- [Download __Source-Code__](https://github.com/totaljs/openplatform)
- Install NPM dependencies via terminal `$ npm install` in the root of application
- Update connection strings in `/config` file
- Run it `$ node index.js`
- Open `http://127.0.0.1:8000` in your web browser
- :fa fa-warning: __IMPORTANT__: Then open settings and configure the platform

Default credentials:

```secret
- login     : __info@totaljs.com__
- password  : __admin__
```

```video
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Qud6SlIUQM
```

__Docker Hub__:

```bash
docker pull totalplatform/openplatform
docker run --env DATABASE='postgresql://user:pass@hostname/database' -p 8000:8000 totalplatform/openplatform
````

__Docker Compose__:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/totaljs/openplatform.git
cd openplatform
docker compose up
````

```video
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rnIAoXOIjG4
```

## Localization

According to your language, download the file below, unzip, translate and store it as `/resources/en.resource`.

- [Download __en.resource__](https://github.com/totaljs/openplatform/tree/master/resources)
- rename it according to the language `en.resource` or `de.resource` or etc.

items.name: Predefined helpers
items.body:
## Predefined Tangular helpers

__Empty__ `Thelpers.empty([def_value])`:

```html
{{ value.null | empty }} a default value will be read from DEF.empty
{{ value.null | empty('---') }}
```

---

__Number formatting__ `Thelpers.format(decimals)`:

```html
{{ value.number | format(2) }}
```

---

__Date formatting__ `Thelpers.format(format)`:

```html
{{ value.date | format('yyyy-MM-dd') }} a custom formatting
{{ value.date | format('[date]') }} with the format read from environment
{{ value.date | format }} a default formatting stored in DEF.dateformat
```

---

__Pluralize__ `Thelpers.pluralize(format)`

```html
{{ value.beers | pluralize('# zero beers,# beer,# two-three-four beers,# five and more') }}
```

- `#` will be replaced with a number

---

__Code list__ `Thelpers.cl(name)`

```html
{{ value.statusid | cl('status') }} will return "name" property from the DEF.cl.status
```

- `DEF.cl.yourname` must contain array in the form `[{ id: String, name: String }]`

- `#` will be replaced with a number

---

__Currency__ `Thelpers.currency(name)`

```html
{{ value.price | currency('eur') }} will render a value according to the DEF.currencies.eur
```

Example:

```js
DEF.currencies.eur = val => val.format(1) + ' EUR';
DEF.currencies.usd = val => '$' + val.format(2);
```


items.name: Is it possible to create my own templates or components?

Of course. You can't use anything from the predefined parts in the UI Builder. Our recommendation is to create an app template, which will be sent directly to the UI Builder, if you want to use something of your own. Your app template must contain a list of UI components and a root component.

Clone one of the existing templates and update it to suit your needs: <https://github.com/totaljs/uibuilder/tree/main/public/templates>

items.creator: Peter Širka

items.name: Intro
items.body:
The code editor supports a custom login mechanism. If you provide several editor applications, you can use your own IAM for user management.

Open the code settings and set the `login` URL address to your API endpoint. The code editor will send two types of request to the same URL address:

__Login__:

```request
POST https://youriam.com/endpoint/
{
	"type": "login",
	"ua": "Chrome",
	"ip": "IP address",
	"url": "Code URL address",
	"code": "Code name",
	"email": "user email",
	"password": "password"
}
```

__Check session__:

```request
POST https://youriam.com/endpoint/
{
	"type": "session",
	"ua": "Chrome",
	"ip": "IP address",
	"url": "Code URL address",
	"code": "Code name",
	"id": "petersirka", // user identifier
	"email": "petersirka@gmail.com"
}
```

API must return an answer in the form:

__User profile__:

```js
{
	"id": "petersirka", // must be defined in lower case without any special characters
	"name": "Peter Širka",
	"email": "petersirka@gmail.com",
	"position": "Developer",
	"sa": true
}
```

or __Error__:

```js
[
	{
		"error": "Invalid credentials"
	}
]
```

items.name: Intro
items.body:
Total.js Code editor supports public API for creating apps. First, you need to set an access token in the Code settings.

__Supported functionality__:

- [Create app](#)
- [Restart app](#)
- [Stop app](#)
- [Remove app](#)
- [List of apps](#)

## Create app

This endpoint creates a new app.

```request
POST https://yourcode.com/apps/create/?token=YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN

{
	"url": "https://www.totaljs.com",
	"template": "https://yourcdn.com/app-template.zip",
	"compose": false,
	"release": false
}
```

- `url {String}` URL must be defined as a hostname with HTTP protocol targeted at your server to cause creating SSL certificates.
- `template {String}` must contain URL or absolute server local path to the __ZIP ARCHIVE__ only
- `compose {Boolean}` optional, runs docker compose instead of standard docker image (default: `false`)
- `release {Boolean}` optional, runs the app in release mode (default: `false`)

__Response__:

```js
{ success: true, value: 'project_id' }
```

## Restart app

This endpoint restarts app.

```request
POST https://yourcode.com/apps/restart/?token=YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN

{
	"id": "https://www.totaljs.com"
}
```

- `id` can be `project_id` or a URL address

__Response__:

```js
{ success: true }
```

## Stop app

This endpoint stops app.

```request
POST https://yourcode.com/apps/stop/?token=YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN

{
	"id": "https://www.totaljs.com"
}
```

- `id` can be `project_id` or a URL address

__Response__:

```js
{ success: true }
```

## Remove app

This endpoint will remove app.

```request
POST https://yourcode.com/apps/remove/?token=YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN

{
	"id": "https://www.totaljs.com"
}
```

- `id` can be `project_id` or a URL address

__Response__:

```js
{ success: true }
```

## List of apps

This endpoint returns a list of apps with a small chunk of the log file. 

```request
GET https://yourcode.com/apps/list/?token=YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN
```

__Response__:

```js
[
	{
		"id": "z1sp001pr41d",
		"name": "App name",
		"url": "https://appdomain.com",
		"created": "2023-03-12T13:48:31.792Z",
		"isexternal": false,
		"logfile": "> DEBUG PID: 321831 ...",
		"running": true,
		"stats": { id: 'e8c397939c9d', cpu: 0, mem: 25, net: 10 }
	}
]
```

items.name: Intro
items.body:
__OpenReports__ is a lightweight app for generating simple reports from the PostgreSQL database.

- __MIT license__
- [OpenReports on GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/openreports)
- Supports [Total.js Extensions](/extensions/)
- [__Support Total.js Platform__](https://www.totaljs.com/community/)

## Installation

- [Node.js +v14](https://nodejs.org)
- [download the project from GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/openreports):

```bash
$ cd openreports
$ npm install
```

Update the `/config` file by adding a connection string to the PostgreSQL database.

```bash
$ npm start
```

## How does it work?

First, you need to create a view of properties and their possibilities:

```js
{
	"id": "investors",
	"name": "Investors",
	"sql": "SELECT a.name, a.email, a.countryid, a.vs, a.language, a.firstname, a.lastname, a.gender, a.phone, a.isonline, ROUND(a.deposits, 2) AS deposits, ROUND(a.balance, 2) AS balance, ROUND(a.reserved, 2) AS reserved, dtbirth, a.company FROM tbl_user a WHERE a.isremoved=FALSE",
	"fields": [
		{
			"column": "name",
			"name": "Investor",
			"type": "string",
			"group": true
		},
		{
			"column": "firstname",
			"name": "First name",
			"type": "string",
			"group": true
		},
		{
			"column": "lastname",
			"name": "Last name",
			"type": "string",
			"group": true
		},
		{
			"column": "countryid",
			"name": "Country",
			"type": "string",
			"group": true
		},
		{
			"column": "vs",
			"name": "Variable symbol",
			"type": "string",
			"group": true
		},
		{
			"column": "gender",
			"name": "Gender",
			"type": "string",
			"group": true
		},
		{
			"column": "phone",
			"name": "Phone number",
			"type": "string",
			"group": true
		},
		{
			"column": "email",
			"name": "E-mail address",
			"type": "string",
			"group": true
		},
		{
			"column": "company",
			"name": "Company",
			"type": "string",
			"group": true
		},
		{
			"column": "isonline",
			"name": "Online",
			"type": "boolean"
		},
		{
			"column": "deposits",
			"name": "Vklady",
			"type": "number",
			"format": 2
		},
		{
			"column": "balance",
			"name": "Balance",
			"type": "number",
			"format": 2
		},
		{
			"column": "reserved",
			"name": "Reserved",
			"type": "number",
			"format": 2
		},
		{
			"column": "dtbirth",
			"name": "Birth date",
			"type": "date",
			"group": true
		}
	]
}
```

Then you can create reports graphically according to the views you have created.

items.name: How does it work?
items.body:
Total.js Flow v10 uses the built-in Total.js framework's FlowStream algorithm. The algorithm is wrapped in [the Total.js FlowStream module](https://github.com/totaljs/flow/blob/master/modules/flowstream.js) and extended by additional functionality. The Flow allows you to create multiple FlowStreams. Each FlowStream works as an independent Child process/Worker-Thread, and it includes design, its components, and variables. The FlowStream can be packaged into a separate FlowStream component that can be used in another FlowStream. Communication between FlowStreams is provided via the main app via [__IPC__](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inter-process_communication). < :far fa-lightbulb-o: __Good to know__:
The main Flow process is something like a proxy server which allows you to manage FlowStreams. It ensures communication between the main Flow process and child processes. The FlowStream can provide its own HTTP server and other stuff around it (each child process / worker thread is an independent application). ![FlowStream](/download/10ept001po51d-19te32a-1280x1000-1.png) The FlowStream module allows you to run FlowStream designs independently (outside of the Total.js Flow app) or without a designer. ## Interesting links - [The FlowStream worker app](https://github.com/totaljs/flowstreamworker) runs the FlowStream designer without UI, and the design can be provided via the cluster. - [FlowStream execution app](https://github.com/totaljs/flowstreamexec) can execute a FlowStream design in Serverless architecture - [Flow Designer](https://github.com/totaljs/flowdesigner) is an independent designer, it can edit FlowStream design via WebSocket

items.name: Installation
items.body:
Todomator (MIT license) is a task manager app for small teams up to 30 members (recommended).

- :far fa-life-ring #E73323: [__Free online chat support__](https://t.me/totaljs/6031) 
- [__Todomator website__](https://todomator.com/)
- [Repository on GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/todomator/)
- [Need help? __Professional support__](https://www.totaljs.com/support/)
- [Commercial support](https://www.totaljs.com/support/)
- [Service-level agreement (SLA)](https://www.totaljs.com/support/)

## Installation

:fa fa-warning: WARNING: Please do not execute `database.sql`, this script will use Todomator internally.

__Manual installation__:

- Install latest version of [__Node.js platform__](https://nodejs.org/en/)
- Install PostgreSQL
- Create a database for the Todomator
- [Download __Source-Code__](https://github.com/totaljs/todomator)
- Install NPM dependencies via terminal `$ npm install` in the root of application
- Update connection strings in `/config` file
- Run it `$ node index.js`
- Open `http://127.0.0.1:8000` in your web browser
- :fa fa-warning: __IMPORTANT__: Then open settings and configure the platform

Default credentials:

```secret
- login     : __info@totaljs.com__
- password  : __admin__
```

__Docker Hub__:

```bash
docker pull totalplatform/todomator
docker run --env DATABASE='postgresql://user:pass@hostname/database' -p 8000:8000 totalplatform/todomator
````

__Docker Compose__:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/totaljs/todomator.git
cd todomator
docker compose up
````

## Localization

According to your language, download the file below, unzip, translate and store it as `/resources/en.resource`.

- [Download __en.resource__](https://github.com/totaljs/todomator/tree/master/resources)
- rename it according to the language `en.resource` or `de.resource` or etc.
- then set your language to a specific user or you can change it globally in the `config` file

items.name: Intro
items.body:
First, you need to obtain a Todomator access token. The token should be generated in the Todomator settings. --- < __API reference__:
You can find it in the URL address of your instance in the form: `https://yourinstance.com/tapi/`. ## How to make a request? ```request POST https://yourinstance.com/api/ X-Token: your-access-token Content-Type: application/json { schema: 'tickets_clone/{id}', data: { name: 'Cloned ticket', status: false } } ``` - `schema {String}` references to `endpoint.id + endpoint.params` - `data {Object}` references to `endpoint.input` __Response__ to create/update/remove operations is in the form: ```js { success: true, value: 'identifier' } ``` ## Todomator + Total.js Flow We have prepared a really elegant Flow component that automatically integrates all available Todomator endpoints into the Flow. Then you will be able to change or create upcoming tickets in Todomator as easily as never before. The Flow component is called `tapi` and it's available for all Total.js Enterprise members. __Are you interested?__ [Contact us](https://www.totaljs.com/community/)

items.name: Intro
items.body:
__BannerSystem__ is an open-source banner system for portals and websites. Run, set up your advertising areas (banners) and add ad campaigns. It's a very helpful web app with easy use.

- __MIT license__
- [Website](https://www.totaljs.com/bannersystem/)
- [BannerSystem on GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/bannersystem)
- [__Support Total.js Platform__](https://www.totaljs.com/community/)

## Installation

- [Node.js +v18](https://nodejs.org)

__Docker__:

```bash
$ docker pull totalplatform/bannersystem
$ docker run -p 8000:8000 -d totalplatform/bannersystem
```

__or__ [download the project from GitHub](https://github.com/totaljs/bannersystem):

```bash
$ cd bannersystem
$ npm install
$ npm start
```

items.name: POST https://api.totaljs.com/weather/
items.body:
It returns a current weather for the defined address.

- __API returns__ `JSON` data

__Total.js__:

```js
TotalAPI('weather', 'Bratislava', callback);
```

__REST__:

```request
POST https://api.totaljs.com/checkvat/
Content-Type: application/json
X-Token: YOUR_TOKEN

{
	"value": "Bratislava"
}
```

__Input data__:

- `value {String}` required, it must contain an address

#### Response

__Success__:

```js
{
	name: 'Bratislava',
	temperature: 22,
	wind: 20.2,
	humidity: 65,
	pressure: 1018,
	cloud: 25,
	uv: 6,
	sky: 'Partly cloudy'
}
```

__Error__:

```js
[{ name: '...', error: '...' }]
```

items.name: POST https://api.totaljs.com/chatgpt/
items.body:
The method asks ChatGPT / OpenAPI.

- __API returns__ `JSON` data

__Total.js__:

```js
var response = await API('TAPI', 'chatgpt', 'What is Total.js Platform?').promise();
```

__REST__:

```request
POST https://api.totaljs.com/checkvat/
Content-Type: application/json
X-Token: YOUR_TOKEN

{
	"value": "What is Total.js Platform"
}
```

__Input data__:

- `value {String}` required, a question for ChatGPT
- `output {text|image}` optional, default `text`
- `size {small|medium|large}` optional, it works with output `image`

#### Response

__Success__:

```js
{
	text: 'Total.js Platform is a web development platform that provides a comprehensive set of tools and modules for building modern, scalable, and high-performance web applications. It is based on the Node.js runtime and offers a seamless development experience with a powerful, intuitive, and easy-to-use framework. Total.js Platform includes features such as database integration, real-time communication, server-side rendering, RESTful API support, and more. It also supports various front-end technologies and integrates seamlessly with popular third-party libraries and services, making it a great choice for building full-stack web applications.'
}
```

__Error__:

```js
[{ name: '...', error: '...' }]
```
